threat.name: Data interception
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Data interception involves unauthorized parties gaining access to data as it is being transmitted over the network. This threat compromises the confidentiality and integrity of data sent via AWS Direct Connect, potentially leading to data breaches and unauthorized access to sensitive information.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The main threat agents include cybercriminals, malicious insiders, and state-sponsored actors. Attack vectors include man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks, compromised network devices, and physical tapping of communication lines.

Impacts

Data interception can result in confidentiality breaches, data integrity compromise, operational disruption, reputational damage, and financial loss.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker intercepts communication between an on-premises network and AWS by positioning themselves between the endpoints, allowing them to eavesdrop or inject malicious data into the communication stream.

threat.name: Unauthorized access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unauthorized access refers to individuals gaining access to AWS Direct Connect resources without proper authorization. This can occur due to weak access controls, compromised credentials, or configuration errors, leading to potential data breaches and unauthorized manipulation of resources.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The main threat agents include cybercriminals, malicious insiders, and attackers exploiting compromised credentials. Attack vectors include stolen or weak passwords, misconfigured IAM policies, and exploitation of insufficiently restricted network access.

Impacts

Unauthorized access can result in data breaches, loss of sensitive information, unauthorized changes to configurations, financial loss, and reputational damage. It compromises the integrity and confidentiality of the AWS environment.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker gains access to AWS Direct Connect resources by exploiting weak or stolen credentials, allowing them to view or manipulate sensitive data. Another scenario involves a misconfigured IAM policy that inadvertently grants excessive permissions to a user, leading to unauthorized actions within the AWS environment.

threat.name: Insecure configuration
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Insecure configuration involves improper setup of AWS Direct Connect resources, leading to potential vulnerabilities. Misconfigurations can result from errors in security settings, inadequate access controls, or failure to follow best practices, exposing the infrastructure to various threats.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The main threat agents include system administrators, attackers exploiting configuration errors, and automated tools scanning for vulnerabilities. Attack vectors include misconfigured access controls, incorrect security group settings, and failure to apply updates or patches.

Impacts

Insecure configurations can lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, service disruptions, and potential exploitation of vulnerable systems. These issues can compromise the security and integrity of data and services.

Example Attack Scenarios

An administrator mistakenly configures overly permissive access controls, allowing unauthorized users to access sensitive data through AWS Direct Connect. Another scenario involves outdated security settings that an attacker exploits to gain unauthorized access, leading to data breaches and service disruptions.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: BGP hijacking
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

BGP hijacking involves malicious actors rerouting internet traffic by corrupting the Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) routing tables. This allows attackers to intercept, monitor, or manipulate data intended for legitimate network paths, potentially impacting AWS Direct Connect's communication routes.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The main threat agents include cybercriminals, state-sponsored actors, and rogue network operators. Attack vectors involve manipulating BGP announcements to falsely advertise ownership of IP prefixes, causing traffic to be misrouted through the attackerâ€™s network.

Impacts

BGP hijacking can lead to data interception, traffic analysis, disruption of services, loss of data integrity, and potential data breaches. It can cause significant operational disruptions and loss of trust in network security.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker corrupts BGP routing tables to divert traffic from a corporate network to their own servers, allowing them to capture sensitive information transmitted via AWS Direct Connect. Another scenario involves an attacker using a compromised or rogue router to announce false BGP routes, disrupting service availability and causing a loss of connectivity for critical applications.

An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

  • Vectors: Utilizing packet sniffing tools on unencrypted networks, executing man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks, and exploiting unsecured Wi-Fi or legacy communication protocols.

Impacts:

  • Exposure of sensitive or confidential data.
  • Potential identity theft, financial loss, and privacy breaches.
  • Increased risk of subsequent attacks due to compromised credentials.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker intercepts unencrypted traffic on a public Wi-Fi network, capturing login credentials and personal data during a client-to-database transaction.
  2. A man-in-the-middle attack is executed on a system that uses unencrypted HTTP connections, allowing the attacker to modify or eavesdrop on critical communications.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Attackers gain unauthorized access due to weak authentication
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Weak authentication mechanisms, such as the absence of multi-factor authentication, simple passwords, or outdated protocols, can enable attackers to bypass security controls and gain unauthorized access to the database. This compromises the integrity and confidentiality of the data stored.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, opportunistic hackers, and insider threats.
  • Vectors: Brute-force attacks, credential stuffing, social engineering, and exploitation of default or easily guessable credentials.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive or confidential data.
  • Data manipulation, exfiltration, or deletion.
  • Increased risk of lateral movement within the network and subsequent security breaches.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker uses automated tools to perform a brute-force attack on a database account protected by a weak password, eventually gaining administrative access.
  2. A hacker leverages stolen credentials from a previous breach to access the database, exploiting the absence of multi-factor authentication to bypass security measures.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Attackers exploit SQL injection vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
SQL injection vulnerabilities occur when user input is improperly sanitized, allowing attackers to inject malicious SQL code into queries. This can lead to unauthorized data access, data manipulation, or complete system compromise.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, opportunistic hackers, and script kiddies.
  • Vectors: Exploiting unsanitized input fields in web applications, abusing vulnerable API endpoints, and leveraging automated tools to identify and attack SQL injection flaws.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data.
  • Data manipulation, deletion, or corruption.
  • Potential escalation of privileges and broader network compromise.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker inputs malicious SQL code into a web form that lacks proper sanitization, retrieving confidential customer records from the database.
  2. A hacker exploits a vulnerable API endpoint to inject SQL commands that alter or delete critical data, causing significant service disruption.

weakness.name: CWE-1004
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1004: Sensitive Cookie Without 'HttpOnly' Flag The product uses a cookie to store sensitive information, but the cookie is not marked with the HttpOnly flag. The HttpOnly flag directs compatible browsers to prevent client-side script from accessing cookies. Including the HttpOnly flag in the Set-Cookie HTTP response header helps mitigate the risk associated with Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) where an attacker's script code might attempt to read the contents of a cookie and exfiltrate information obtained. When set, browsers that support the flag will not reveal the contents of the cookie to a third party via client-side script executed via XSS.

A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-400

weakness.name: CWE-434

weakness.name: CWE-539
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-539: Use of Persistent Cookies Containing Sensitive Information The web application uses persistent cookies, but the cookies contain sensitive information. Cookies are small bits of data that are sent by the web application but stored locally in the browser. This lets the application use the cookie to pass information between pages and store variable information. The web application controls what information is stored in a cookie and how it is used. Typical types of information stored in cookies are session identifiers, personalization and customization information, and in rare cases even usernames to enable automated logins. There are two different types of cookies: session cookies and persistent cookies. Session cookies just live in the browser's memory and are not stored anywhere, but persistent cookies are stored on the browser's hard drive. This can cause security and privacy issues depending on the information stored in the cookie and how it is accessed.

countermeasure.name: Conduct frequent configuration reviews
countermeasure.desc:
Regularly review system and server configurations to ensure that security settings are properly implemented and sensitive data is not exposed. Conducting configuration reviews helps identify misconfigurations, weak access controls, and other vulnerabilities that could lead to unauthorized access or data leakage.

Implementation Steps:

Define Configuration Review Scope:

  • Include critical configurations such as access controls, encryption settings, user permissions, and network configurations in the review.
  • Ensure compliance with security best practices and regulatory requirements (e.g., GDPR, PCI DSS).

Review Access Controls:

  • Verify that only authorized users have access to sensitive data and critical systems.
  • Ensure that default credentials and unnecessary accounts are removed or disabled.

Check Data Protection Settings:

  • Ensure that sensitive data is encrypted both in transit (using TLS) and at rest (using strong encryption algorithms like AES).
  • Review file permissions to ensure that sensitive files are not accessible to unauthorized users.

Examine Security Policies and Rules:

  • Regularly audit security policies, firewall rules, and network configurations to ensure they are up to date and provide the necessary protection.
  • Verify that logging and monitoring systems are correctly configured to detect any suspicious activity.

Document and Act on Findings:

  • Document all findings from the configuration reviews and prioritize actions to address non-compliant configurations or identified vulnerabilities.
  • Implement changes and re-test configurations to ensure they align with security standards.

Schedule Regular Reviews:

  • Perform configuration reviews quarterly or after significant changes to the environment (e.g., updates, new deployments).
  • Use automated tools to assist with the review process, making it more efficient and thorough.

By conducting frequent configuration reviews, organizations can ensure that security settings are correct, minimizing the risk of exposure and ensuring that sensitive data remains protected.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-53: Security and Privacy Controls

countermeasure.name: Enforce role-based access controls and multi-factor authentication
countermeasure.desc:
Implement role-based access controls (RBAC), multi-factor authentication (MFA), and the principle of least privilege to minimize unauthorized access to internal systems and resources. By ensuring that only authorized personnel have access to necessary data and systems, these measures reduce the risk of accidental or intentional misuse of sensitive information and limit exposure to attacks.

Implementation Steps:

Configure Role-Based Access Control (RBAC):

  • Define roles within your organization and assign permissions based on job responsibilities. Ensure that each user has access only to the resources necessary for their role.
  • Regularly review and update roles to reflect any changes in job functions or responsibilities.

Implement Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA):

  • Require MFA for all users accessing critical systems or sensitive data. This ensures that even if credentials are compromised, unauthorized access is still prevented.
  • Use authentication methods like mobile apps, hardware tokens, or biometrics alongside passwords.

Enforce the Principle of Least Privilege:

  • Ensure that users, systems, and applications have the minimum level of access required to perform their tasks.
  • Review and adjust access levels periodically to ensure they remain aligned with users' current roles.

Audit and Review Access Logs:

  • Regularly audit access logs to ensure that access controls are being properly enforced and that no unauthorized access has occurred.
  • Implement alerts to notify administrators of suspicious or anomalous access attempts.

Educate and Train Users:

  • Provide ongoing training to users on secure access practices, including how to use MFA and why least privilege is important.
  • Educate users about the risks of privilege escalation and how to securely manage their credentials.

By enforcing these access control measures, developers and DevOps engineers can reduce the risk of unauthorized access and ensure that only the appropriate personnel can access sensitive resources.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-53: Access Control

countermeasure.name: Ensure server software is up-to-date with security patches
countermeasure.desc:
Regularly update all server software, including operating systems and applications, with the latest security patches. Keeping software up-to-date reduces the risk of exploitation due to known vulnerabilities. Establish a patch management process to ensure timely updates and minimize exposure to security threats.

Implementation Steps:

Establish Patch Management Process:

  • Develop a formal patch management policy that includes patch assessment, approval, and deployment procedures.
  • Prioritize patches based on their severity and impact on server security.

Automate Patching for Critical Systems:

  • Use automation tools to deploy critical patches as soon as they are available to minimize the window of vulnerability.
  • Ensure that automatic updates are enabled for operating systems and essential applications.

Test Patches in a Staging Environment:

  • Before applying patches to production systems, test them in a staging environment to ensure they do not cause system instability or conflicts with other software.

Regularly Review Security Bulletins:

  • Subscribe to security mailing lists, such as those from software vendors and organizations like CVE or NIST, to stay informed about the latest vulnerabilities and patches.
  • Monitor patch release cycles for both operating systems and third-party applications to apply patches promptly.

Track Patch Compliance:

  • Implement a monitoring system to track which systems have received the latest patches and generate compliance reports.
  • Perform regular audits to ensure that all critical systems are patched according to the defined policy.

Maintain Backup Before Applying Patches:

  • Ensure that a backup of the server and critical data is taken before applying patches, to facilitate recovery in case of issues.

By ensuring that all server software is regularly updated with the latest security patches, organizations can significantly reduce their exposure to security vulnerabilities.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-40: Guide to Enterprise Patch Management Technologies

countermeasure.name: Install and configure antivirus and IDS/IPS systems
countermeasure.desc:
Install and maintain antivirus software and intrusion detection/prevention systems (IDS/IPS) on internal servers to monitor and protect against malware attacks. These systems detect, prevent, and alert on malicious activities by analyzing server traffic and system behavior. Regularly update antivirus signatures and IDS/IPS rules to enhance their effectiveness in identifying new threats. Ensure that alerts are reviewed promptly to take immediate action against potential malware infections.

Implementation Steps:

Install Antivirus Software:

  • Deploy antivirus software on all internal servers to scan for and eliminate known malware.
  • Ensure that automatic updates for antivirus definitions are enabled to keep the system up-to-date.

Configure IDS/IPS:

  • Set up intrusion detection/prevention systems to monitor network traffic and server behavior for suspicious activities.
  • Regularly update IDS/IPS signatures and detection rules to stay ahead of emerging threats.

Configure Alerting and Logging:

  • Set up alerts for any detected malware or suspicious activities to notify system administrators immediately.
  • Ensure that detailed logs are maintained for all detected events to allow for post-incident analysis and troubleshooting.

Regular Updates and Patching:

  • Schedule routine updates for both antivirus and IDS/IPS software to ensure vulnerabilities are patched and signatures are up to date.
  • Perform periodic reviews of the effectiveness of the systems in place.

Test Effectiveness:

  • Run periodic tests and simulations to ensure that antivirus and IDS/IPS systems are identifying threats effectively and responding in real time.

By implementing antivirus and IDS/IPS systems, developers and DevOps engineers can minimize the risk of malware infections and ensure continuous monitoring of the internal server environment.

countermeasure.name: Restrict physical access with security measures
countermeasure.desc:
Implement strict physical security measures to restrict unauthorized access to servers and sensitive areas. Use biometric authentication, CCTV surveillance, and secure facility access policies to control who can access critical systems. Ensure that only authorized personnel can enter data centers or server rooms, reducing the risk of tampering, theft, or physical damage to the servers.

Implementation Steps:

Install Biometric Authentication:

  • Implement biometric systems (e.g., fingerprint or retina scans) to control access to sensitive areas like server rooms and data centers.
  • Ensure biometric systems are integrated with facility access control systems to track and log access attempts.

Set Up CCTV Surveillance:

  • Deploy CCTV cameras at key entry points and throughout sensitive areas to monitor and record access.
  • Store video footage securely and ensure it is reviewed periodically for security threats or breaches.

Establish Secure Access Policies:

  • Create access control policies that define who is authorized to enter critical areas and under what conditions.
  • Ensure that all access is logged and periodically audited to identify unauthorized attempts.

Implement Security Personnel and Alarms:

  • Use security guards and alarm systems to monitor facility access, ensuring unauthorized individuals are immediately detected.
  • Integrate alarm systems with access logs to trigger alerts if unauthorized access is attempted.

Enforce Role-Based Physical Access:

  • Limit access to the most sensitive areas to personnel with a need-to-know basis, using role-based access controls for physical access.

By applying physical security measures, organizations can prevent unauthorized physical access to critical infrastructure, reducing the risk of tampering, theft, or other malicious activities.

References:

  • Physical and Environmental Security

countermeasure.name: Use DDoS protection services and traffic filtering
countermeasure.desc:
Implement DDoS protection services, rate limiting, and traffic filtering to defend against Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks. These measures help mitigate the impact of overwhelming traffic on the internal server by filtering malicious traffic, controlling the rate of incoming requests, and redirecting suspicious traffic to secure environments for analysis. Regularly update and configure these services to adapt to evolving attack techniques.

Implementation Steps:

Enable DDoS Protection Services:

  • Use cloud-based DDoS protection services, such as AWS Shield, Azure DDoS Protection, or Google Cloud Armor, to detect and mitigate large-scale attacks.
  • Configure the service to automatically detect and mitigate traffic spikes that may indicate a DDoS attack.

Implement Rate Limiting:

  • Set up rate limiting to restrict the number of requests that can be made to the server within a specific time frame, preventing an overload of the serverâ€™s resources.
  • Use API gateways or web application firewalls (WAF) to enforce rate limits for critical services.

Configure Traffic Filtering:

  • Implement traffic filtering mechanisms to block malicious traffic and allow only legitimate requests from trusted sources.
  • Use tools like Web Application Firewalls (WAF) or reverse proxies to filter out harmful traffic, such as SQL injection attempts or bot traffic.

Monitor Traffic for Anomalies:

  • Set up real-time traffic monitoring to detect anomalies such as sudden spikes in traffic or unusual request patterns.
  • Use centralized logging and alerting systems to notify security teams of potential DDoS attacks.

Regularly Test and Update Protection Mechanisms:

  • Regularly perform stress tests to assess the effectiveness of DDoS protection services and traffic filtering configurations.
  • Keep DDoS protection systems updated with the latest detection rules and algorithms to defend against new attack vectors.

By implementing DDoS protection services, rate limiting, and traffic filtering, developers and DevOps engineers can significantly reduce the risk and impact of DDoS attacks, ensuring better availability and stability of internal services.

References:

  • Denial of Service Cheat Sheet

countermeasure.name: Use encryption protocols for data in transit and data at rest
countermeasure.desc:
Use strong encryption protocols such as TLS (Transport Layer Security) for data in transit and ensure that data at rest is encrypted with secure algorithms like AES (Advanced Encryption Standard). Encryption protects sensitive information from unauthorized access, both during transmission over the network and when stored on servers. Regularly review encryption configurations and update protocols to ensure they comply with the latest security standards and prevent vulnerabilities.

Implementation Steps:

Enable TLS for Data in Transit:

  • Configure all server communication (e.g., HTTP, API calls) to use TLS 1.2 or higher.
  • Ensure certificates are valid, up to date, and issued by trusted certificate authorities (CAs).
  • Enforce strong ciphers and disable outdated versions (e.g., SSL, TLS 1.0/1.1) to ensure secure communication.

Encrypt Data at Rest:

  • Use strong encryption algorithms (e.g., AES-256) to encrypt sensitive data stored on the server, including databases, file systems, and backups.
  • Store encryption keys in a secure key management system (KMS) to prevent unauthorized access.

Configure Key Management:

  • Implement a secure process for key generation, storage, and rotation.
  • Ensure that encryption keys are rotated periodically and are not hardcoded in the application code.

Monitor and Audit Encryption Configurations:

  • Regularly audit encryption settings to ensure compliance with industry standards and organizational policies.
  • Use automated tools to monitor encryption protocols and identify any weaknesses or misconfigurations.

Stay Updated with Encryption Standards:

  • Regularly review and update encryption methods and algorithms to adhere to the latest security guidelines and best practices.
  • Ensure that encryption methods are aligned with regulatory requirements, such as GDPR or PCI DSS.

By applying encryption for both data in transit and data at rest, developers and DevOps engineers can protect sensitive information and reduce the risk of unauthorized access.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-53: Security and Privacy Controls

threat.name: Attackers try to gain unauthorized access

Attackers attempt to bypass authentication mechanisms to gain unauthorized access to the internal server, potentially compromising sensitive data or systems.

  • External Attackers: Hackers attempting to exploit weak authentication mechanisms or stolen credentials.
  • Internal Attackers: Employees or contractors attempting to access restricted systems without proper authorization.
  • Vectors: Brute-force attacks, stolen credentials, and social engineering.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized System Access: Attackers gain access to sensitive systems or data.
  • Data Loss or Theft: Once inside, attackers can steal or alter critical data.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Phishing Attack: Attackers trick legitimate users into revealing their credentials to access the system.

threat.name: Attackers cause information leakage through misconfigurations

General Threat Description

Misconfigurations in the system can lead to unintentional exposure of sensitive information to unauthorized parties.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Hackers exploiting publicly accessible misconfigurations to gain sensitive data.
  • Internal Attackers: Insiders taking advantage of poor configuration practices.
  • Vectors: Misconfigured file permissions, open ports, or exposed services.

Impacts

  • Exposure of Sensitive Data: Confidential information is unintentionally exposed to unauthorized users.
  • Compliance Violations: Breaching data protection regulations due to improperly configured access controls.

  • Misconfigured Cloud Storage: Insecure cloud storage settings lead to exposure of files or credentials.

threat.name: Attackers attempt to steal sensitive data

Attackers target sensitive data stored on the server, attempting to steal or exfiltrate it for malicious purposes.

  • Data Breach: Sensitive information such as customer data or proprietary information is exposed or stolen.

countermeasure.name: Adopt capacity-aware, multi-Availability Zone placement strategies
countermeasure.desc:
Step-by-Step Guidance for Implementing the Countermeasure:

1. Use Multiple Instance Types and Launch Templates

To reduce potential disruptions caused by infrastructure limitations within a single Availability Zone (AZ), leverage multiple EC2 instance types and launch templates:

  • Analyze workload requirements to select compatible EC2 instance families/types that meet compute, memory, storage, and networking needs.
  • Create launch templates for each instance type, specifying key configuration details such as AMI, instance type, security group, and block device mappings. Follow AWS Launch Template Guidance for detailed instructions.
  • Test launch templates in your development environment to confirm compatibility and performance.

2. Configure Auto Scaling Groups Across Multiple Availability Zone Subnets

To achieve high availability and fault tolerance, distribute workloads across multiple subnets tied to different AZs.

  • Identify subnets associated with distinct AZs within your VPC. Ensure your VPC is configured correctly (Subnet Documentation).
  • Create or update Auto Scaling Groups (ASGs) to span these subnets, specifying multiple AZs during ASG configuration.
  • Set ASG scaling policies based on workload demand or health checks to dynamically allocate resources.

3. Monitor and Plan Service Quotas Per Availability Zone

AWS imposes quotas on resources per region and AZ, which can lead to capacity constraints. To avoid service disruptions:

  • Use the AWS Service Quotas dashboard to monitor quotas for critical resources like EC2 instances, EBS volumes, and Elastic IPs.
  • Plan resource allocations carefully while scaling across AZs and request quota increases as needed using AWS Service Quotas Console.
  • Automate monitoring of service quotas using Amazon CloudWatch.

4. Validate That Critical Workloads Can Start in Alternate Availability Zones

Ensure failover capabilities for critical workloads in case one AZ becomes unavailable:

  • Test the deployment of your applications in alternate AZs by simulating failure scenarios.
  • Review resource dependencies (e.g., EBS volumes and IP addresses) and ensure configurations allow for quick replication or reassignment in another AZ.
  • Create Disaster Recovery (DR) plans to guide workloads' transition within minutes of AZ disruptions.

5. Continuously Evaluate and Audit Configuration

Regularly audit your architecture and workload distribution across AZs to identify security and operational risks.

  • Use AWS Config to set up rules for continuous compliance checks.
  • Review AWS Trusted Advisor recommendations to optimize availability configurations and verify AZ balance.
  • Conduct routine penetration testing and failure drills for detecting vulnerabilities and validating failover mechanisms.

  • AWS Global Infrastructure
  • AWS EC2 Launch Templates
  • AWS Service Quotas

countermeasure.name: Constrain egress per Availability Zone using NAT, routes, and endpoints
countermeasure.desc:
Step 1: Deploy NAT Gateways Per Availability Zone

To ensure high availability and fault tolerance, deploy a NAT Gateway in each Availability Zone within your VPC.

  • Navigate to the Amazon VPC console.
  • In the navigation pane, select NAT Gateways and then click Create NAT Gateway.
  • Select the subnet corresponding to the Availability Zone where the NAT Gateway will reside.
  • Allocate or select an Elastic IP address to associate with the NAT Gateway.
  • Repeat this process for all relevant Availability Zones in your VPC.

Step 2: Bind Private Subnets to Same-Zone NAT Gateways

Assign route tables to private subnets and ensure traffic destined for the internet is routed through NAT Gateways in the same Availability Zone.

  • In the Amazon VPC console, select Route Tables.
  • Choose a route table associated with a private subnet.
  • Edit routes to add a destination of 0.0.0.0/0 and set the target to the NAT Gateway's ID specific to the same Availability Zone.
  • Associate the route table with the private subnet in the Subnet Associations tab.
  • Repeat these steps for all private subnets to ensure zonal redundancy.

Step 3: Restrict Egress with Route Tables and Network ACLs

Limit the outbound traffic from private subnets to the minimum necessary to reduce the attack surface.

  • Configure the route table to direct only necessary traffic to specific destinations via the NAT Gateway.
  • Set up Network ACLs (NACLs) to explicitly allow specific protocols, ports, and IP ranges necessary for your applications.
  • Ensure a default "Deny" rule for other outbound traffic.

Step 4: Prefer VPC Endpoints for AWS Service Traffic

Leverage VPC endpoints (interface or gateway endpoints) to route traffic to AWS services directly within the AWS network, avoiding public internet routes.

  • Navigate to the Amazon VPC console and select Endpoints.
  • Click Create Endpoint and select the desired AWS service, such as S3 or DynamoDB.
  • Choose the appropriate Endpoint type (gateway or interface) based on the service.
  • Associate the endpoint with the relevant route tables within your VPC.
  • Test and verify traffic to AWS services flows through the endpoint instead of the NAT Gateway.

  • VPC Security Best Practices
  • Amazon VPC NAT Gateway Documentation
  • Amazon VPC Endpoints Documentation
  • Network ACLs Documentation

countermeasure.name: Design multi-Availability Zone architectures for fault isolation
countermeasure.desc:
To improve the security and resiliency of your workload in AWS, follow the step-by-step guidance below for distributing critical resources across multiple Availability Zones (AZs):

  1. Determine the number of Availability Zones and Regions: Analyze the workload requirements to identify suitable AWS Regions and the number of Availability Zones available in each Region. Refer to the AWS Availability Zone documentation to find detailed information.
  2. Create separate subnets for each Availability Zone: Design your Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) with subnets distributed across multiple AZs. Each AZ should have a dedicated subnet to ensure proper resource isolation and failover capabilities. Follow the guidelines in the AWS VPC User Guide for subnet creation.
  3. Configure Auto Scaling Groups across multiple subnets: Create an Auto Scaling Group (ASG) and specify the subnets in multiple AZs to ensure instances can launch in alternative AZs during an outage. Enable dynamic scaling policies to maintain a consistent level of performance. Review the AWS Auto Scaling documentation for step-by-step setup instructions.
  4. Use Multi-AZ deployments for managed services: For database services like Amazon RDS, enable Multi-AZ deployment to provision a standby replica in a secondary AZ. This setup automatically performs failover during disruptions. Additionally, validate Multi-AZ support for other managed services, such as Amazon ElastiCache and Amazon DynamoDB. Use the Amazon RDS Multi-AZ documentation for more information.
  5. Implement replication across Availability Zones: Configure data replication mechanisms that span AZs for critical datasets. For example, enable S3 cross-region replication or use the replication features provided by databases like Amazon DynamoDB Global Tables and Amazon Aurora. Reference the Amazon S3 Replication documentation.
  6. Validate failover and recovery processes: Conduct periodic failover testing to ensure seamless transitions during AZ outages. Validate that your Auto Scaling Groups, Multi-AZ services, and data replication mechanisms work as intended under simulated failure scenarios. Review AWS Well-Architected Framework guidelines for best practices.
  7. Monitor AZ health and implement alerts: Use AWS CloudWatch to monitor the performance and health of resources across AZs. Create alarms to detect anomalies or failures early, and set up SNS notifications to ensure real-time alerts for critical events. Refer to the Amazon CloudWatch documentation for guidance.
  8. Optimize cost and compliance considerations: Ensure your workload is distributed efficiently to avoid unnecessary costs while adhering to regional compliance requirements. Use AWS Cost Explorer and AWS Config to maintain visibility into cost and security configurations. Refer to the AWS Cost Explorer documentation.

countermeasure.name: Harden per-Availability Zone network segmentation
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps to implement the security countermeasure for AWS Availability Zones effectively:

  1. Design the Subnet Architecture:
    • Create distinct public and private subnets in each Availability Zone within your VPC.
    • Ensure public subnets are used for resources requiring internet access, such as load balancers.
    • Place resources such as application servers or databases in private subnets to prevent direct internet exposure.
  2. Configure Security Groups:
    • Apply the principle of least privilege when creating and configuring security groups. Ensure they allow only explicitly required traffic.
    • Examples: Restrict access to application servers to specific IP ranges or allow database ports only from application servers.
    • Allocate separate security groups for different resource tiers (e.g., web, application, database).
  3. Set Up Network Access Control Lists (NACLs):
    • Create NACLs for subnets to define fine-grained network-level policies for inbound and outbound traffic.
    • Implement deny rules for traffic that must explicitly be blocked, alongside allowing necessary traffic.
    • Regularly review NACL rules to optimize security settings.
  4. Create Dedicated Route Tables:
    • Assign dedicated route tables for each subnet tier to ensure isolation and control over routing.
    • Public subnetsâ€™ route tables should include routes to an internet gateway (IGW), allowing internet-based communication.
    • Private subnets should have routes directing traffic through a NAT gateway or VPC endpoint, without routing traffic to the IGW.
  5. Leverage VPC Endpoints:
    • Use VPC endpoints to privately access AWS services such as S3, DynamoDB, or Systems Manager without the need for public internet access.
    • Subnet traffic directed to VPC endpoints will stay entirely within the AWS network, improving security.
    • Ensure proper IAM policies on the VPC endpoints to enforce access controls for the associated AWS service.
  6. Regularly Review Routes:
    • Inspect route tables periodically to identify any unintended routes that may expose resources to unauthorized access or create conflicts.
    • Remove unnecessary routes and test changes thoroughly before deployment.
    • Monitor changes in route tables using AWS Config to ensure compliance with your network security policies.

For further details and best practices, consult the following references:

  • VPC Security Best Practices
  • AWS Infrastructure Security Basics

countermeasure.name: Implement Availability Zone-scoped logging and monitoring
countermeasure.desc:
Step-by-Step Guidance for Implementing the Security Countermeasure:

1. Enable VPC Flow Logs for Each Subnet

VPC Flow Logs provide visibility into the IP traffic handled by your VPC. By enabling flow logs at the subnet level, you gain granular insights into traffic patterns and potential issues.

  • Log into the AWS Management Console.
  • Navigate to the VPC section of the console.
  • Select the target VPC and then locate the specific subnets within it.
  • Click on the subnet you want to enable logs for and choose Create Flow Log.
  • Specify the destination for the logs (e.g., CloudWatch Logs or an Amazon S3 bucket).
  • Choose appropriate filters (e.g., All, Accept, Reject).
  • Save your settings and repeat for all relevant subnets.

2. Enable AWS CloudTrail Across All Regions

AWS CloudTrail provides event history and auditing capabilities for actions occurring within your AWS account. You should ensure CloudTrail is globally enabled and centralized for all regions.

  • Navigate to the CloudTrail console.
  • Click Create trail.
  • Provide a name for your trail and enable logging across All Regions.
  • Specify where logs should be stored (e.g., an Amazon S3 bucket).
  • Configure optional encryption and permission settings for enhanced security.
  • Validate the trail creation and ensure monitoring is enabled for Availability Zone activity.

3. Centralize Logs in Amazon CloudWatch Metrics/Alarms

To gain insights into anomalous traffic behavior and monitor configuration drift, integrate logs with CloudWatch and set up metrics and alarms with dimensions for Availability Zones.

  • Navigate to the CloudWatch console.
  • Ensure you have enabled log ingestion from VPC Flow Logs and AWS CloudTrail.
  • Inside the console, create Log Groups to centralize logs related to traffic patterns in specific Availability Zones.
  • Define Metric Filters to extract key metrics from logs, such as large spikes in denied traffic or unexpected changes.
  • Create alarms using CloudWatch thresholds to alert when unusual behavior is identified.
  • Test alarms and validate their alignment with Availability Zone identifiers.

4. Continuously Monitor for Configuration Drift

Configuration drift occurs when the infrastructure gradually diverges from its intended state. Detect and mitigate it using AWS Config and automated corrective actions.

  • Enable AWS Config to monitor resource configurations across your account.
  • Use Config rules to track compliance with security best practices, focusing on VPC security, flow logs, and trail settings.
  • Create custom Config rules to log and alert for changes in subnet configurations or flow log status.
  • Integrate relevant insights into CloudWatch dashboards for centralized visibility.

5. Detect Anomalous Traffic Patterns

Leverage specific AWS tools to detect unusual or harmful traffic patterns across Availability Zones.

  • Integrate Amazon GuardDuty to analyze flow logs and CloudTrail events for threats.
  • Enable DNS threat detection and monitor unusual spikes or requests within Availability Zones.
  • Regularly audit metric alarms and identify high-traffic periods that donâ€™t correlate with expected behavior.
  • Implement runtime protection tools to respond to live traffic anomalies.

countermeasure.name: Restrict inter-Availability Zone connectivity with least privilege
countermeasure.desc:
To improve the security of AWS Availability Zone implementations, follow these comprehensive steps:

  1. Scope Security Group Rules to Necessary Ports and Sources:

    • Decide which ports are required based on the specific functionality of the application or workloads hosted within the Availability Zone.
    • Restrict inbound and outbound traffic to only the ranges of IPs or VPC resources that require access.
    • For each security group, use precise CIDR ranges or specific AWS resources (i.e., other security groups or instance IDs) to define allowed traffic. Ensure the rules comply with the principle of least privilege.
    • Review the configurations frequently to ensure that only necessary access is permitted and to detect any unused or overly permissive rules.
    • To implement, navigate to the Security Groups section in your AWS Management Console or use the AWS CLI/SDK.

  2. Segment Tiers per Availability Zone:

    • Design your application tiers (e.g., web, app, and database tiers) to align with specific Availability Zones. This provides a natural layer of segmentation for additional security.
    • Configure security group rules to ensure that lateral movement is restricted between tiers, except for explicitly required communication flows. For example, only allow the application tier to communicate with the database tier.
    • Use subnet segmentation within Availability Zones to isolate traffic dynamically based on the application tier's role. Each tier can be assigned its own subnet with distinct configurations.

  3. Use ALB/NLB Target Groups with Controlled Registration Across Zones:

    • Configure Target Groups in your Application Load Balancer (ALB) or Network Load Balancer (NLB) to register instances based on specific Availability Zones.
    • Verify that health checks are configured properly to ensure that only healthy instances are registered in Target Groups.
    • Control registration by tagging or labeling instances according to their purpose and zone, and create IAM policies or scripts for automated instance registration based on exclusion or inclusion criteria.
    • Use listener rules in your ALB or NLB to enforce zone-specific routing if necessary.

  4. Review NACLs to Minimize Lateral Movement:

    • For each subnet in your VPC, review Network Access Control List (NACL) rules to ensure that only legitimate traffic flows are allowed.
    • Block unnecessary intra-zone traffic by explicitly denying overly permissive rules, especially those allowing access between subnets of different tiers unnecessarily.
    • Use deny rules explicitly where feasible to block traffic that should not have lateral access across subnets and Availability Zones.
    • Regularly audit NACL rules using AWS Config to ensure compliance with best practices and monitor for drift or outdated configurations.

References

  • VPC Security Best Practices
  • Amazon EC2 Security Groups
  • What Is an Application Load Balancer?
  • Network Load Balancer Overview
  • Network ACL Overview
  • AWS Config Evaluation of Rules

countermeasure.name: Use stable Availability Zone ids and avoid hardcoded names
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure resources in AWS are distributed across distinct physical zones and maintain high availability, adhere to the following steps:

  1. Understand AWS Availability Zone IDs:
    • Availability Zones are distinct from "names" such as us-east-1a. These names vary per account due to internal mapping, but Availability Zone IDs (e.g., use-az1) remain consistent across accounts.
    • Refer to the AWS documentation on Availability Zone IDs to familiarize yourself with this concept: Availability Zone Concepts.
  2. Use Programmatic Discovery via the AWS CLI or SDK to dynamically retrieve Availability Zone information:
    • Run the following AWS CLI command to list all Availability Zones within a region:aws ec2 describe-availability-zones --region REGION_NAMEReplace REGION_NAME with your selected region (e.g., us-east-1).
    • In the output, reference the ZoneId fields (e.g., use-az1). These IDs can be used reliably to distribute resources across distinct physical locations.
  3. Automate Resource Spreading Across Zones:
    • Design your infrastructure to programmatically spread workloads across the unique ZoneId values using orchestration tools such as AWS CloudFormation, AWS SDK (for Python boto3 or Java SDK), or APIs.
    • Create deployment logic to verify that the resources are evenly distributed by cross-checking the ZoneId mappings during deployment or updates.
  4. Document the ZoneId mappings:
    • Maintain a record of Availability Zone IDs and their associated resources for each deployment or major change.
    • Store this documentation securely in a versioned repository or centralized configuration management system, such as AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store or an internal inventory system.
  5. Continuously Audit Resource Placement:
    • Periodically run the DescribeAvailabilityZones API or CLI command and validate the resource placement against the mapping records for consistency.
    • Update deployment documentation promptly if new zones are added or existing ones are modified.

  • Availability Zone Concepts

threat.name: Single Availability Zone dependency causing regional service outage impact
threat.desc:
General threat description
Workloads located in a single AWS Availability Zone are exposed to disruptions resulting from zonal failures, scheduled maintenance, or capacity constraints, posing risks to service continuity and data accessibility.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Zonal failures may arise from natural disasters, hardware malfunctions, or network issues. Planned maintenance or sudden demand spikes may also contribute to decreased availability.
Impacts
The impacts include potential outages, temporary or permanent loss of data, degradation of application performance, and loss of trust or revenue resulting from service disruptions.
Example Attack Scenarios
A hardware failure within an Availability Zone causes a widespread outage, bringing down critical applications hosted in that zone. Alternatively, a planned maintenance event reduces resource availability, resulting in service degradation for all workloads relying exclusively on that zone.

threat.name: Availability Zone identifier mismatch across accounts causing misplacement
threat.desc:
General threat description
Hardcoding the names of Availability Zones can lead to resources being placed in unintended physical zones due to the variability in how names map to physical zones across accounts, which can compromise redundancy and failover strategies.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unintentional misconfiguration by developers or operators, reliance on incorrect documentation, or automated deployment scripts that do not account for differing zone mappings.
Impacts
Potential lack of high availability, increased risk of resource failure in disasters, and compromised system reliability due to violated redundancy and failover assumptions.
Example Attack Scenarios
A developer deploys instances to us-east-1a, assuming it corresponds to a specific physical zone across all accounts, but the mapping differs in their organizationâ€™s AWS account, placing resources in the same physical zone as other critical systems. A failure in this zone leads to a cascading outage.

threat.name: Capacity and placement risk within an Availability Zone
threat.desc:
General threat description
Zonal capacity constraints or inflexible placement strategies can restrict the ability to scale or perform failovers during disruptions, leading to system downtime or reduced service availability.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Misconfigurations, resource limitations, or improper distribution of workloads can exacerbate zonal constraints and lack of effective placement mechanisms.
Impacts
Reduced service availability, inability to recover from disruptions, and potential customer dissatisfaction due to reliability issues.
Example Attack Scenarios
A sudden increase in resource demand overwhelms a specific Availability Zone, and the inability to migrate workloads to another zone results in degraded performance or service outages. Alternatively, rigid placement strategies restrict scalability, preventing efficient allocation of resources across zones during high loads.

threat.name: Subnet and route misconfiguration exposing Availability Zone resources
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) design can lead to unintended exposure of instances or services within an Availability Zone to networks or the internet, compromising isolation and security.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers may exploit shared route tables, misconfigured public subnets meant to be private, or overly permissive network ACLs to gain unauthorized access or disrupt services.
Impacts
Potential impacts include data breaches, unauthorized access, service disruptions, or exploitation of exposed resources for malicious activities.
Example Attack Scenarios
An organization accidentally configures a public subnet instead of a private one, inadvertently exposing critical services to the internet. Attackers notice and exploit misconfigured ACLs to access sensitive data or disrupt internal services.

threat.name: Cross-Availability Zone traffic exposure due to broad network rules
threat.desc:
General threat description
Overly permissive configurations in security groups or network ACLs can inadvertently create unintended cross-Availability Zone access paths, potentially increasing the impact of a compromise and expanding the blast radius.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors or misconfigured resources can exploit permissive settings to traverse networks across zones, accessing unauthorized systems or data in other Availability Zones.
Impacts
Unauthorized access can lead to data breaches, service disruptions, and escalation of security incidents across multiple zones, reducing the isolation benefits of Availability Zones.
Example Attack Scenarios
A misconfigured database in one zone with an overly permissive security group gets exploited by an attacker, who then pivots to access sensitive systems in other zones through unintended network paths, amplifying the impact of the event.

threat.desc:

Attackers may exploit misconfigured routing tables, overly permissive NAT gateway rules, or unmonitored outbound traffic within the private subnets to establish unauthorized communication channels with external entities.
Impacts
Compromise of sensitive data, unauthorized remote control of instances, or exploitation of the infrastructure for malicious activity, which could lead to financial, reputational, and operational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker might exploit a misconfigured routing table to redirect traffic from instances to a malicious server on the internet, extracting sensitive information. Alternatively, compromised instances could use a shared NAT gateway to contact a command-and-control server, initiating further attacks or lateral movement within the environment.

threat.name: Unrestricted VPN traffic
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unrestricted VPN traffic occurs when VPN tunnels are configured to allow all traffic without filtering, exposing the network to unnecessary risks. Without proper traffic controls, malicious actors or unauthorized users could gain access to sensitive resources and perform unauthorized actions within the network.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Attackers or unauthorized users could exploit the open access provided by unrestricted VPN traffic. Common vectors include brute-force attacks, lateral movement within the network, or malware that utilizes the VPN tunnel for data exfiltration.

Impacts

Unrestricted VPN traffic can lead to unauthorized access to critical systems, data breaches, malware infections, and compliance violations. The lack of granular control increases the attack surface, making the network more vulnerable to internal and external threats.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Scenario 1: A user gains VPN access but can reach more sensitive parts of the network than intended due to an overly permissive VPN configuration.
  • Scenario 2: An attacker compromises a user's credentials and uses the VPN to explore and escalate privileges within the network, accessing sensitive data or launching further attacks.

threat.name: Vulnerable IKE negotiation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Vulnerable Internet Key Exchange (IKE) negotiations occur when weak or outdated versions of the IKE protocol are used to establish a VPN connection. IKE vulnerabilities can be exploited during the VPN tunnel setup, leading to interception of key exchanges or man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks, compromising the security of the VPN connection.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include attackers exploiting weaknesses in IKE versions, such as IKEv1, which is prone to known vulnerabilities. Attack vectors include intercepting IKE messages, brute-forcing Diffie-Hellman key exchanges, or manipulating the session to gain unauthorized access to the VPN.

Impacts

Successful exploitation of vulnerable IKE negotiations can lead to compromised VPN connections, interception of sensitive data, unauthorized access, or the ability to decrypt VPN traffic. This could result in data breaches, loss of confidentiality, and potential regulatory non-compliance.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Scenario 1: An attacker intercepts IKEv1 negotiations and exploits known vulnerabilities to access the VPN traffic and gain unauthorized access to the network.
  • Scenario 2: During the IKE phase, an attacker uses a weak Diffie-Hellman group to compromise the key exchange, allowing them to decrypt sensitive data transmitted over the VPN.

threat.name: Inadequate key exchange mechanisms
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Inadequate key exchange mechanisms occur when weak or outdated cryptographic algorithms, such as low-strength Diffie-Hellman (DH) groups, are used during VPN negotiations. These vulnerabilities can compromise the security of the VPN, allowing attackers to intercept or decrypt key exchanges, resulting in unauthorized access to sensitive data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Attackers could exploit weaknesses in key exchange mechanisms by leveraging brute-force attacks, intercepting Diffie-Hellman key exchanges, or exploiting known vulnerabilities in outdated Internet Key Exchange (IKE) configurations. The use of weak DH groups or older IKE versions (e.g., IKEv1) exposes the system to cryptographic attacks.

Impacts

If the key exchange is compromised, attackers can potentially decrypt traffic, gain unauthorized access to encrypted data, or even impersonate trusted systems, leading to significant security breaches, data exposure, and non-compliance with security regulations.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Scenario 1: An attacker takes advantage of a VPN tunnel using a low-strength Diffie-Hellman group to compromise the key exchange and decrypt sensitive data transmitted over the VPN.
  • Scenario 2: A network administrator uses an outdated IKE version (IKEv1) with known vulnerabilities, allowing an attacker to manipulate the key exchange and gain unauthorized access to encrypted communications.

threat.name: Insecure VPN tunnels
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Insecure VPN tunnels occur when weak encryption or misconfigurations leave data transmitted between on-premises systems and AWS vulnerable to interception or decryption.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Attackers may exploit outdated encryption protocols, such as weak Diffie-Hellman groups, or use man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks to intercept or alter VPN traffic.

Impacts

Sensitive data exposure, unauthorized access to the network, and potential data breaches.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Scenario 1: An attacker exploits weak encryption in a VPN tunnel to intercept confidential communications.
  • Scenario 2: An outdated IKE version is compromised, allowing unauthorized access to encrypted data.

threat.name: Unmonitored VPN traffic
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unmonitored VPN traffic occurs when there is insufficient logging or monitoring of data being transmitted over the AWS Site-to-Site VPN. Without proper oversight, suspicious or malicious activities, such as unauthorized access or data exfiltration, can go undetected, potentially leading to data breaches or network compromise.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers leveraging weaknesses in the VPN configuration, or insiders transmitting unauthorized traffic. Attack vectors may include attempts to bypass security controls, malware using VPN traffic to exfiltrate data, or unauthorized access due to lack of traffic inspection.

Impacts

Undetected security incidents, unauthorized access, and data breaches, leading to financial loss, legal repercussions, and reputational damage. Organizations may fail to meet compliance requirements that mandate monitoring of sensitive traffic.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Scenario 1: A malware-infected device uses the VPN tunnel to exfiltrate data. Without monitoring in place, the malicious activity remains undetected.
  • Scenario 2: An unauthorized user gains access to the VPN but remains unnoticed due to a lack of real-time traffic monitoring, allowing lateral movement within the network.
